journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Discrete wavelet transform–neural network crack-like damage identification of welds on chassis cross members

article-meta.aff: 1Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, K.N. Toosi University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
2School of Mechanical Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Yadollah Rezvani, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, K.N. Toosi University of Technology, 470 Mirdamad Avenue West, 19697 Tehran, Iran. Email: farhad.rezvani.g@gmail.com

abstract.p: This paper incorporates a discrete wavelet transform and a radial basis function neural network to implement a vibration-based crack-like damage identification approach to the simulated welds of chassis cross members. After finite element method modelling of a vehicle, eight acceleration sensors are placed on the chassis, and their responses are measured to the upward displacement on the excitation of two tyres while the other two tyres are fixed. Then, a discrete wavelet transform with a Daubechies 3 mother wavelet is applied to the responses of the sensors. All detail coefficients and approximation coefficients of the nine levels of the discrete wavelet transform are introduced into the radial basis function neural network, in order to extract the underlying features for assessment and localization of damage. This approach successfully assesses the existence of damage and the localization of various lengths of damage in numerically simulated vehicle chassis welds, with respect to the fact that the complete model of the vehicle is a highly complicated structure and its vibration responses are extremely non-linear and sophisticated.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The non-destructive damage identification (NDI) of crack-like defects in structures has received substantial consideration during the last three decades.1 These cracks are mainly caused by the manufacturing process or by fatigue and exhibit a serious threat to the performance of structures. These practical issues have led to the development of NDI techniques. The main idea of these techniques is based on analysing the variation in the dynamic behaviour of the structure (caused by damage).2,3 As in modal-vibration-based analyses, the defects change their natural frequencies, damping ratios and mode shapes. These NDI techniques could be categorized in four steps: detection, localization, quantification and estimation of the remaining service life. One of the most common categories of damage detection methods is modal-vibration-based methods.3 Dimarogonas4 and Chondros5 used a local flexibility model, obtained from experiments, as a crack in structures and introduced a spectral method based on the changes in the first three natural frequencies. Chondros and Dimarogonas6 discussed the change in the dynamic behaviour of a cantilever beam, which is caused by a crack in its welded joints. Their results showed that the change in the beam’s natural frequency can give information on the existence of a crack and possibly an estimation of its depth. Banks et al.7 used the variations in the stiffness and the damping ratio to detect the size and location of the damage. The need for complete dynamic analysis of a structure means that the implementation of modal-based techniques encounters serious difficulties, particularly in the case of complex structures.3,8 Therefore, new damage detection techniques have been investigated.

Early new methods were based on the application of a Fourier transform (FT) that transforms a signal from the time (or space) domain to the frequency domain. Because of loss in the time (or space) details of data, Fourier-based methods are unable to determine the time (or space) of the occurrence of damage. Later, in order to eliminate this disadvantage of the FT-based method, the windowing technique called the short-time Fourier transform (STFT) has been proposed.9–11 Furthermore, in order to improve the limited precision of the fixed-size analysing window in the STFT method, the wavelet transform (WT) method with a variable-size analysing window was proposed, preserving all details of a signal in the time (or space) and frequency domains. Therefore, the WT is able to analyse a signal locally. The WT, briefly, breaks up a signal into shifted and scaled versions of a mother wavelet.12

The WT-based method can be categorized into different groups.13 In the first group, the WT and the wave propagation theory are employed in which the WT analyses the response signals. The shortest path arrival time of the flexural waves caused by damage is assessed by locating the peaks of the wavelet coefficients. Then localization or quantification of damage is carried out using different methods. For example, Salehian et al.14 solved the inverse problem of determining the applied load location (which models the structural damage) using a set of non-linear equations. Li et al.15 proposed a damage detection method based on a continuous wavelet transform (CWT) and employed this technique to analyse a flexural wave in a cracked beam, in which the flexural wave was obtained from finite element method (FEM) modelling. In the second group which contains most of the WT-based methods, because the existence of damage results in discontinuities in the dynamic responses of a structure, identification, localization and/or quantification of damage can be carried out. Extracting the damage features from the modulus matrix of the CWT coefficients or the discrete wavelet transform (DWT) detailed signals of the structure responses, the approaches of this group inferred the existence or the occurrence time of damage. Using the spatial wavelet theory, Liew and Wang16 calculated wavelets along the beam length based on the numerical solution of the beam deflection, where the beam was excited by a rapid oscillation. Finding a peak (discontinuity) in the wavelet coefficients, the crack was located. By means of modelling the crack as local decreases in the density and the stiffness of a rod, Castro et al.17 used a CWT on free longitudinal vibrations for damage detection. The damage was localized with the presence of peak in the CWT, while the defect quantification was performed through a linear relationship between the amplitude of the peak and the defect intensity. Finally, in the last group, the changes in the wavelet coefficients of the damaged structure from a healthy structure are employed to detect damage. For example, Surace and Ruotolo18 identified the existence of cracks in a beam using this category of WT-based method.

Since fatigue and ill-conditioned manufacturing can cause crack-like damages in the welds of chassis cross members which attached to the chassis frame and these welds are under continuous road forces through the suspension system, health monitoring or damage detection in these welds is crucial. Moreover, implementation of the previously mentioned approaches for complex structures as chassis is either extensively complicated or even impractical. Therefore, this paper proposes a vibration-based approach for structural crack-like damage identification in vehicle chassis cross members using a DWT and a radial basis function neural network (RBFNN). The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In the methodology section, the WT, the RBFNN and the proposed approach on the simulated chassis are introduced. Then, in the results and discussion section, the results of the implementation are discussed while, in the final section, the conclusions of this study are drawn.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: In this section, the WT and RBFNN concepts are introduced. Then, the modelling process of a theoretical example is described.

sec.title: Wavelet transform
sec.p: Nowadays the concept of a WT has been deployed widely in digital signal processing, numerical analysis, physics and engineering. Straightforwardly, wavelets may be understood as localized waves. This means that wavelets are constrained signals which drop to zero after a few oscillations, with zero mean value.19,20 A mother wavelet, used in wavelet analysis, is oscillatory and a large amount of its energy is restricted to a bounded interval. Unlike the FT, where the signal is decomposed into only sinusoidal functions, various mother wavelets, based on the features of the original signal, can be chosen. Also, a repeatedly mentioned term in the terminology of mother wavelets, namely ‘compact support’, refers to the fact that, in finite intervals, the values of the basis function are not vanishing, which results in efficient recognition of the signal’s localized features. The scaling (dilating or compressing) and translating of the mother wavelet in time constitutes a set of mother wavelets, called a wavelet family, given by the expression

where a and b are the scale parameter and the translation parameter respectively. Then, the CWT of a signal

Considering infinitely small (very narrow windows) and infinitely large (very wide windows) positive values for a leads to a convenient choice for high-frequency and low-frequency components respectively of the signal
g

. According to Rioul and Vetterli,21 the time resolution, thus, becomes arbitrarily good at high frequencies, while the frequency resolution becomes arbitrarily good at low frequencies; by this means, the wavelet overcomes the fixed-size time–frequency resolution limitation of the STFT. Based on the admissibility condition of the mother wavelet,22 the CWT is a collection of inner products of a signal
g
( t )
and the translated–scaled wavelets.20

The original signal

The process of breaking down the signal into the detail and approximation coefficients may be understood as low- and high-pass filtering of the signal in such a way that the number of samples is reduced in each level of decomposition. This procedure is clearly illustrated in Figure 1, which shows that the signal is decomposed into three levels using the DWT.

caption.p: Wavelet decomposition scheme for a three-level analysis.

sec.title: Radial basis neural network
sec.p: Radial basis functions (RBFs) appeared as an alternative to artificial neural networks in the late 1980s and have been successfully applied to a large diversity of applications. An RBFNN is an RBF embedded in a two-layer feedforward neural network; the hidden layer implements a radial activation function, and the output layer implements a weighted sum of hidden unit outputs.

Geometrically, an RBF represents a bump in the multi-dimensional space, whose dimension is given by the number of entries. The influence of the activation function decreases while the Euclidian norm (the distance) from the centre of the RBF increases. Since a multiple-output RBFNN can always be converted into a group of single-output RBFNNs, here for notational simplicity the scalar-output case is considered (as shown in equation (7)). A schematic diagram of the n-input scalar-output RBFNN is depicted in Figure 2, which implements a mapping

sec.p: In application of an RBFNN to pattern classification, the inputs represent the feature entries, while each output corresponds to a class and the hidden units correspond to the subclasses. Furthermore, the performance of the RBFNN does not decisively depend on the choice of the non-linear RBF type. However, the Gaussian function is preferred in pattern classification applications and is given by

where the standard deviation

The neural network models the underlying function of a certain mapping.

Since parameter estimation is frequently ill conditioned, more developed techniques such as singular value decomposition24 or the orthogonal least-squares algorithm25 have to be employed. Because a detailed description of the learning algorithm seems redundant in this text, the present authors advise readers to refer to RBF references such as the book by Howlett and Jain.26 The updating of network parameters is implemented such that they minimize a cost function mean square error given by

sec.title: Theoretical example modelling
sec.p: In order to implement vibration-based crack-like damage detection in the chassis of the vehicle, the body of the vehicle is modelled in CATIA software. Then, the three following steps are conducted, successively.

list-item.p: Pre-processing. Using HYPERMESH software, an FEM model is constructed from the primary model and the properties such as meshing, loading and materials are determined.
Processing. Through NASTRAN analyser software, in this stage, the behaviour of the constructed model is analysed.
Post-processing. Data acquired from previous stages are extracted in the form of diagrams or numerical data.

sec.p: In the FEM model, the following elements are used: a quadratic hexagonal shell, a spring, a rigid link and beam elements. The quadratic hexagonal elements are deployed in the body of the vehicle model. The spring elements consist of two nodes where each node has six degrees of freedom. In the modelling of the bush, mount and tyre-to-ground joint, six, three and three springs respectively are used. Mass elements are concentrated at a point and are used instead of several parts of the vehicle body such as the engine, seats and tyres at their centre-of-mass position. Rigid joints cause a rigid connection between a master node and other slave nodes. Furthermore, chassis cross members are modelled by beam elements. Joints of the body panels and the chassis cross member to the chassis frame are attached by a spot and line weld. In order to model these welds, the surrounding points of the weld in two engaging plates are attached by beam and rigid elements. In Figure 3, the FEM model of the chassis frame is depicted and the overall vehicle FEM model is shown in Figure 4. Finally, hinges are modelled by multi-point constraint and rigid elements.

caption.p: FEM model of the chassis: objects 1 to 5 are the cross members; objects 11 to 14 and objects 21 to 24 are the sensors.
FEM model of the overall vehicle.

sec.p: The elasticity modulus, Poisson’s ratio and the density of the materials used in the vehicle model are illustrated in Table 1. Also, the overall mass of the vehicle is 1450 kg. Crack-like damage in the welds of chassis cross members is modelled by eliminating the connection(s) between two or three successive nodes. The lengths of these cracks are in the range 2.5–5 cm.

caption.p: Detailed characteristics of the materials in the vehicle model.

sec.p: Theoretical examples of loading and boundary conditions are chosen as real set-ups in vehicle test laboratories. A pair of diagonal wheels are displaced 5 mm vertically for the loading condition, and the two other diagonal wheels are fixed in all directions for the boundary condition.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: First, eight acceleration sensors (recording the vertical accelerations at eight different points at 601 Hz) are placed on the sides of the chassis frame. Then, a DWT with a Daubechies (db) mother wavelet (with nine level of decomposition) is deployed to pre-process the acceleration data of the chassis. Now, the criteria for selecting the db wavelet as the convenient mother wavelet are presented. To apply WT analysis on a signal, the first and important step is to select the most convenient mother wavelet. Although there is not an exact way to expedite the procedure and the selection is usually achived by trial and error, the selection could be facilitated by examining the properties of the mother wavelets. Therefore, the selected mother wavelet with application in this study should possess the following properties: regularity, the ability to perform a fast WT transform, and exact reconstruction.

Consequently, because of the complicated structure which leads to highly non-linear and non-stationary acceleration signals, an RBFNN is used to detect damage and its location in cross member welds. The convenient order of the db mother wavelet selection is in direct relation to the RBFNN structure. Therefore, a loop with a db order counter is used and it was observed that the best results in the determination and localization of damage were achieved by using the Daubechies 3 (db3) mother wavelet. All detail coefficients (all nine levels of analysis) and approximation coefficients are considered as the input of the neural network; the size of the input vector is 5304. Moreover, the size of the output vector is 10, which is associated with the fact that the chassis has five cross members and that each cross member has two sides. In order to form training pairs for the neural network, crack-like damage is created 147 times in various locations of the cross member welds with different lengths and a DWT is applied to the resulting acceleration data. Also, note that the acceleration data for the healthy structure are recorded and analysed by a DWT to determine whether the structure is healthy or damaged. The spread parameter of the centre is set manually with trial and error.
To verify the model, model analysis is conducted on the model without any boundary conditions and its natural frequencies are extracted (illustrated in Table 2).

caption.p: Natural frequencies of the vehicle model.

tr.td: Combinational mode of roll motion and fore–aft motion
Combinational mode of roll and lateral motion
Bending flexible mode of the overall vehicle
Torsion mode of the frame and cabin
First bending mode of the body

sec.p: It was observed that the first six frequencies of the model are equal to zero (the insignificant values of these frequencies are related to numerical computation errors). Because these first six frequencies indicate the rigid motions of the model and these frequencies are equal to zero in the free–free condition of a body, the model is verified.

In order to guarantee that the model is physically and numerically verified, the FEM model is investigated. FEM model control can be divided into two parts: first, the factors that lead to error in the problem-boundary error and the duplicate error; second, the factors that depend on the element type such as the aspect ratio, warpage, skew, taper, Jacobean and face corner angle. These factors lead to errors in solving the problem. Note that the aspect ratio must be less than 5:1, the warpage factor of the shell elements should be less than five, and the phase corner angle of two adjacent sides must be less than 165° and 155° for a triangle and a quadrangle respectively. The control FEM model results are illustrated in Table 3.

caption.p: Verification of the FEM vehicle model.

tr.th: Value for the following types of constraint

sec.p: As depicted in Figure 5, the difference between the acceleration signals (in the damaged and the healthy conditions) is insignificant since the considered intensity of the damage is small. Therefore, there is a need to use signal-processing approaches such as a DWT to enlarge this difference and to be able to propose a meaningful conclusion (determination of the damage location) for this difference.

caption.p: (a) Accelerations of two identical sensors and (b) their differences.

sec.p: Using a DWT, therefore, the significant underlying features of signal are extracted. The detail coefficients and the approximation coefficients up to level nine are illustrated in Figure 6 and Figure 7. The differences between the detail coefficients and the approximation coefficients in these two conditions are depicted in Figure 8.

caption.p: Decomposition of the acceleration signal of the healthy chassis.
Decomposition of the acceleration signal of the damaged chassis.
Difference between the decompositions of the acceleration signal of the damaged chassis and that of the healthy chassis.

sec.p: Although there exists a pattern in the difference between the DWT coefficients of the healthy and the damaged conditions which could be used to detect and localize damage, discerning these patterns require much effort. Furthermore, in some cases such as the theoretical example in this study, finding the underlying patterns is almost impossible. Therefore, an intelligent RBFNN is employed to extract the important features of the underlying patterns to perform damage detection and localization. Also, regarding the limited sets of training samples and the high capability of the RBFNN in classification problems, the RBFNN choice is more convenient than a multi-layer perceptron neural network. In Figure 9, the performance of the RBFNN versus the epoch is shown.

caption.p: Performance of the RBFNN versus the epoch.

sec.p: Note that structural damage information is distributed in various vibration modes, and higher vibration modes (or high frequencies) are more sensitive to small amounts of damage. Since it is not possible to produce large training set, all detail coefficients (which contain high-frequency components) and approximation coefficients (which contain low-frequency components) of the main signal are considered as inputs of the RBFNN.

As mentioned previously, the spread (width) parameters of the RBFs are considered constant and they are obtained through trial and error. As illustrated in Table 4, the spread constants of the middle RBFs (which detect damage in the cross members in the middle of the chassis) are smaller than those of the outer RBFs (which detect damage in the cross members at the ends of the chassis). This means that the centres of the middle RBFs are not distant (smaller spread values) in the RBFNN input space, i.e. the DWT performs a weaker feature extraction or the excitation load is not sufficiently high to produce intensive differences in the features of the vibration responses in this region. Also, as depicted in Figure 3, more complexity on the left-hand side of the chassis than on the right-hand side leads to the smaller spread constants of the left-hand side.

caption.p: Spread constants of all the cross member sides.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Most previous damage detection methods have been applied on simple structures such as a beam while the application of these methods on complicated structures such as a vehicle chassis is either difficult or extremely expensive. Since WT-based methods have demonstrated their effectiveness in detecting the hidden features of non-linear and non-stationary signals which other methods have failed to recognize and since RBFNNs have shown their ability in inferring non-linear maps, in this study a combination of a DWT and an RBFNN is proposed to detect and localize crack-like damage in the chassis cross member welds of a full-model simulated vehicle. The damage feature extraction is achieved by using a DWT while the damage detection and localization is executed by using an RBFNN. This approach successfully detects and localizes damage of various sizes in welds. Also, the results indicate that the applied approach is sensitive to the excitation load in a way that a DWT may fail to extract sufficient features for the RBFNN to detect and localize damage. Furthermore, the damage detection and localization tasks become more rigorous on the damaged part of the chassis, e.g. the middle of the left-hand chassis side in Figure 3. In spite of the fact that this approach is implemented on a full-model vehicle and the excitation load is selected considering its practicality in this numerical study, further work is still needed to make it applicable in real conditions.
